conclusion: Understanding the behavior of an ideal gas on a p-V diagram using the Ideal Gas Law.
State A: p_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3, T_A = 300 K; State B: p_B = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 1 x 10^-3 m^3; State C: p_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
From A to B, volume is constant, indicating an isochoric process. Use Ideal Gas Law: p_A/T_A = p_B/T_B.
Calculate T_B: T_B = (1 x 10^5 Pa x 300 K) / (3 x 10^5 Pa) = 100 K.
From B to C, pressure is constant, indicating an isobaric process. Use Ideal Gas Law: V_B/T_B = V_C/T_C.
The temperature of the gas at state C is 300 K.
